content.rendered:
Charles De Gaulle said, “The better I get to know men, the more I find myself loving dogs.” We know that dogs have long been called man’s best friend, but did you know:

There are at least 150 dog breeds to choose from.
Favorite dog names include Max, Jake, Maggie and molly.
The United States has the most dogs, with one in three families having a furry family member.
The Saluki is the world’s oldest dog, going back to around 2100 B.C., and one will set you back about $2,500.
An adult dog has 42 teeth, which is ten more than his best friend.
A dog can exert up to 230 pounds per square inch of pressure with its bite.
A dog is about as smart as a two-year-old, and may be able to learn up to 1,000 words.
Dogs are omnivores, which means they eat meat, grains and vegetables.
Petting dogs may help reduce blood pressure.
A dogs since of smell is between 1,000 and 10 millions times stronger than that of a human. They can be trained to detect cancer in patients, explosives, and even the glue used in computer storage devices, which has aided in arrests of individuals involved in the trade of child pornography. Dogs can also smell our feelings.
In the United States, service animals are considered “necessary medical equipment.” More recently, service animals have been used to treat emotional issues such as post traumatic stress disorder, or PTSD.
It costs $10 thousand to train a federally certified search and rescue dog.
There are somewhere between 400 and 600 million dogs around the world, and approximately two thirds are strays.
Approximately 67 thousand dogs can come for a single dog and it’s offspring over a six year period, with the average litter being 4 to 6 puppies.
There are nearly 14 thousand animal shelters in North America.
A Basenji is the only dog that doesn’t bark.
A greyhound is the fastest dog, clocking in at up to 45 miles per hour.
The average dog lives between 10 and 14 years, gains about half their body weight in the first 4 to 5 months, and can reach full size in 12 to 14 months.
Puppies sleep an average of 18 to 20 hours.
The average body temperature of a dog is 101.2 degrees Fahrenheit.
Smaller dogs mature faster than larger dogs, but tend to live longer.
Chihuahuas are the shortest dogs, measuring about 6 inches.
Mastiffs are the heaviest dogs, weighing in at about 200 pounds.
No two nose prints are alike.
The Bible mentions dogs more than 35 times, including Luke 16:19-31, Job 30:1, Psalms 22:16 and Matthew 7:6.
According to at least one movie, all dogs go to heaven.
Lassie was the first animal inducted into the Animal Hall of Fame (1969).
Though no animal has ever won an Academy Award, Rin Tin Tin came closest to getting best actor.
Lakia, a Russian dog, was the first dog in space, and traveled around the world nine years after the space money.
Famous dogs include: Dug (from the movie “UP’), Toto (from “The Wizard of Oz”), Snoopy (from Peanuts), Buddy (from “Air Bud”), Dino (from “The Flintstones”), Slink (from “Toy Story”) Astro (from “The Jetsons”), Scooby-Doo (from “Scooby-Doo”), Comet (from “Full House”) and Snoop Dogg (just kidding).
Dog songs include “I Love My Dog” by Cat Stevens, “The Puppy Song” by Harry Nilsson, “Seamus the Dog” by Pink Floyd and “I’m Gonna Buy Me a Dog” by The Monkees.
